content.description: Slopey pinches and big moves mixed with small holds
content.location: Just to the right of The Edge of Glory

content.description: The crux is down low, but it isn't too bad. Someone wrote 5.9 in chalk at the base, and it may take some searching for holds at first. Stick with it, it's all there.
content.location: Right of Yankee Magpie

content.description: Before you can say, "Who in the world would rate this 3/3 stars?!" you will have onsighted and cleaned this route.  Walk up a short slab to the chains.
content.location: The 7th boltline from the left.

content.description: Smaller holds down low, find the arch and it gets easier from there.
content.location: Right of Yankee Magpie and Yankee Strikes Again. There is one more route right of this before the gully and a bolted 5.1 (part of a multi-pitch) that leads to a ledge.

content.description:
Small cobbles lead to big cobbles lead to small cobbles lead to huge cobbles lead to crux at steepness.

The left side of the route milks the dark water streak on the left.

Right or left at the top?  Decisions decisions...

Fun route with a single rowdy crux area.
content.protection:
8 lead bolts straight up to 2 bolt/chain anchor.

Rappel route.  Please don't TR directly off the chains.
content.location:
Just left of Silt in the Saddle Stitching.

Right of Falcon and the Gulo.

Climbs the left side of the shallow arête at the upper crag, just right of the dark water streak.

content.description: The last in a set of four 5.1 routes that are great to set a top rope on for kids to scramble or as a location for anyone to learn how to lead and set top rope anchors on a sport route.  The climb goes up an easy slab to a ledge that is also used as a belay station for Sunshine On My Shoulder (5.11b).  The anchors are located on the wall behind the ledge and are far enough back that you can get lots of rope drag going over the edge.  It may be worth extending the anchor when top roping.
content.protection: Five bolts to a double quick link anchor.
content.location: The next line up trail from Here Comes The Turkey.  Walk five feet past a huge pocket and your there.

content.description: Climb up the 5.1 Super Chicken then head up the headwall. This could eventually become a good climb but right now its dirty and slightly dangerous with rock fall. I worry about rocks falling and hitting the rope because it angles out on the 5.1 part. Take care on this climb!
content.protection: 20 draws. 70 m rope will work from the bottom.
content.location: just right of The Percolater.

content.description: So this is still cleaning up. My partner fell twice doing it with breaking holds. There is a band of softer rock in the mid section. Climb with care.
content.location: 2 climbs to left from King Cobble. There is a belay bolt for safety.

content.description: This route begins in the same alcove as King Kobble and climbs just to the left of the "King Cobble".  Although slightly steeper throughout there is a significant band of loose matrix around the half way point which can make red pointing this route challenging - Tread Lightly.  As always at Maple, a helmet for the belayer is a good idea.
content.location: Begin in the King Kobble alcove.  This is one route left.

content.description:
Nice steep start on big holds.  Lower angle slab at third bolt nicely cryptic.

Hard right avoids steep arête and keeps the grade low.

Big holds up steep face with a shuffle left to the chains.
content.protection: 8 lead bolts to two bolt/chain anchor.  Shares anchor with Tweetie the Condor.
content.location:
Located on the shallow arête between Tweetie the Condor and Fast Times at Wolverine High.

Left side of the scoop at the base on the cliff containing Fast Times to Early Bird Arête.

content.description: This is one of the best beginner routes I have done in Maple, along with Bullets Over Bagdad.  A really long and fun route with a nice view from the top.  It follows the left side of a black arete and so it stays shaded until late morning, unlike the other routes at Early Bird Crag.
content.location: This route lies at the far North end of the Early Bird Crag.  Walk all the way up along the east facing wall until you see a South facing arete directly in front of you.  The route climbs the West face of the arete (morning shade).  The route is separated from the main wall by another shorter, unbolted arete.

content.description:
A nice straight up line on great rock with big cobbles.

A couple of steep parts provide some excitement but the holds keep coming.

Well bolted.
content.protection: 13 lead bolts to a fixed anchor w two bolts/two sets of chains. Very well protected.
content.location: Located to the left of Early Bird Arete.  Shares the first few bolts with that route.

content.description:
First Pitch (5.6)

Pitch begins on black shiny face to the left of a crack.  Clip third bolt with long draw.  After fourth bolt head up and left across crack and up face until you get on blunt arete.  then head to right to ledge with chains

Second Pitch (5.9)

Steep with big moves
content.location: 3 lines to the right of The Edge Of Glory

content.description: Start on right trending ramp, clip first bolt, then head up vertical face to anchors.
content.location: Middle of Early Bird crag.  Just left of the four obvious 5.0 routes on the ribs.

content.description: Climb 'Here Comes the Turkey' (5.1), rest at the ledge, then pull fun moves on large cobbles to the top with good rests. Goes as .12a in the maple guidebook, must be an error or a primitive rating. Nevertheless, good exposure with slightly overhanging jug hauling make it worth a the climb.
content.location: On the arete, the 5.1 is the middle route of three similar climbs. See 'Here Comes the Turkey' for photo

content.description: Book says 11c. But its easier. Go up the easy 5.1. Continue past 2 bolt anchor. Fun climbing. A bit sandy but its cleaning up.
content.protection: Bolts to anchor. 19 draws according to guidebook.
content.location: Climb the line just right of the gap between rock formations. The  further most left climb on the buttress.

content.description:
A classic for sure. No moves are all that difficult by themselves but it is a long one, don't get pumped. Climb this route and stand on the king of all cobbles!

This route is bolted very well, thanks Darren! Goes straight up and uses a full 60m.
content.location: Walk uphill from the Yankee routes, up a steep, loose gulley, double back a bit to the large ledge on your left. Fourth from the left on the large ledge. If you can't tell, go across the gulley and look up at the King.

content.description: Climbs jugs through choss. A bit cleaner than its neighbors. Best to clip a draw on the sun god for your belayer. The knezek Book calls this 11b, I think a few new holds have appeared.
content.location: On far left of belay ledge. Climb the arete.

content.description: Pockets throughout the route with fun big moves between.
content.location: Just to the right of Angry Birds

content.description: Nice slab route to set a top rope on for the kids or as a first time lead.  As with most Maple Canyon routes the bolts are close together. The route ends at anchors on top of a ledge that also forms a belay station for The Percolator (5.12a).  The anchors seemed quite high in position relative to the ledge but were still reachable for purposes of setting a top rope.
content.protection: Six bolts to wide spread quick link / rap ring anchors.  Due to the width between the anchors using short draws to set an opposing gate anchor for top rope may not be suitable.
content.location: When you first come around the corner of the approach trail to the main face of The Early Bird Crag you will see three flakes headed to a ledge directly up trail.  This is the first line of bolts on the face of the third flake.

content.description: Deceivingly steep. Good holds on darkish rock.
content.location: Just right of King Cobble.

content.description:
Steep slab start leads to steep cruxy section.  Followed by big holds and no hands rests prior to the steep finish to the chains.

Fun route.
content.protection: 9 lead bolts to two bolt/chain anchor.
content.location:
Located just left of Return of the Drillslingers.  No need to move the rope.

Rappel route.  Please don't TR from the chains.

content.description: This routes starts out mellow and has a puzzling section where the wall gets steep.  Figure this out and you have it in the bag as the climbing eases to the chains just above this crux.
content.location: Just down hill from Early Bird Arête.  This route is the first route right of Here Comes the Sun.

content.description:
A super fun route on a corner feature. Even though its not super long almost all of the moves require power and a ton of body tension.

An easy start through the first two bolts and then the action begins!!!

A very cool pocket gets you to the fourth bolt and then long moves off small holds will get you to the big hole up high. From there its cruiser climbing to the chains.

This could be a tough one to onsight if 10d is your limit.
content.protection:
7 Bolts.

Two bolts with quicklinks for anchors.
content.location: This route is the third route from the left side of The Early Bird Crag. Eagle Tenders is the route to its left. Scramble up a slab for 30 feet and start the climb.

content.description: A bit exposed, this awesome climb goes smoothly up the arete on the right side of Early Bird
content.location: Right side arete of Early Bird Crag, not quite as far right as Rib Cage. Shares a start with Return of the Drillslingers, which goes straight up instead of branching right onto the arete. Break right onto the arete after the 5th bolt.

climbs.name: Eagle's Nest
climbs.fa: Darren and Jennifer Knezek, Matt Selman

content.description:
Need a

Maple Canyon

hero pic for your collection? This is the perfect route for you!

P1-

This is the crux pitch with a very steep and powerful start.  The crux comes after the 4th bolt, when you are forced onto a short sequence of two tiny crimps and committing moves.  You can also chicken out and do

Eagle Tenders

to the right and join the second pitch of the climb. 30M of 5.10c

P2-

Clip the bolt between the anchors of Eagle's Nest and Eagle Tenders and continue upwards on huge holds. 15M of 5.8

P3-

Easy climbing on huge holds.  Only a few bolts. 15M of 5.6

P4-

Easy but unprotected jaunt across the top of the formation and two gullies, past two bolts to the summit block.  Belay from a two bolt belay for the last few moves. 15M of 5.0

P5-

Pull a bulge onto the summit block and pose for pictures! 20ft of 5.9

Descent:

Rap X3.  Rap from the 5th chains to the third chains.  Then rap from the 3rd to the first chains, and once more to the ground. All with one 60m rope. This is by far the chossiest climb I've done in Maple so be prepared. The belay stations are in good locations to miss falling rock but still bring a helmet and be incredibly careful.  You pass through several seams of rotten rock.  If you've climbed at Maple much, you will recognize them.  It will be many more ascents before this route cleans up.  When it does clean up, it will be a fun route and worth it for the view alone.
content.protection: 12 quickdraws to chains + slings and lockers.
content.location: This is the first route you pass, on the far left side of the wall.

content.description: Start by climbing up a small alcove, clip a few bolts and traverse out onto the face.  You will get a little exposure as you are not far off the ground.  The crux comes in a few more bolts when the holds thin out.  Pull through to a very easy/slabby face for the second half of the climb.  Continue up the next 4 pitches of Eagle's Nest if you wish.
content.location: The second route you encounter as you hike up to the crag.

content.description: Climb the 1st of 3 ribs to anchors at the base of the headwall.  The approach pitch for Morning Buzz (11c).
content.location: Middle of the Early Bird Crag.  1st of the obvious 5.0 bolted ribs.

content.description: Climb the 2nd of three ribs to the base of the headwall.  Can be used as an approach pitch for the Percolater (12a).
content.location: Middle of the Early Bird Crag.  The 2nd of three obvious 5.0 ribs in a row.

content.description: Start on the first pitch of Raven Ridge.  After the 4th bolt, head out right.  You are heading up a ramp, past a crack filled with handfuls of squirming lizards (in the summer), to chains.  Don't let them surprise you!
content.location: Better to have your 2nd follow and clean.  Traverses enough that it's  very awkward to clean when lowering.
